Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Establishing cellular biomarker levels and biological function in lung Cancer
Award.AbstractNarration:
Pteridines are an emerging class of metabolic biomarkers that show promise as noninvasive indicators of malignancies such as lung cancer. Recent advancements in pteridine detection have elucidated the biological function of pteridines and establish cellular levels in cancer cell lines. Using a combination of powerful detection platforms, this study aims to establish cellular pteridines levels in multiple human cell lines in order to propose novel pteridine mechanisms in lung cancer and to generate corresponding pteridine profiles that can be used for clinical screening purposes. These pteridine profiles will enable clinical practitioners to advance pteridine validation studies and facilitate the rapid translation of pteridine diagnostics into clinical practice while mechanism elucidation will enable new anti-cancer technologies. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Huwei Liu, a leading expert in bioseparations, at Peking University which affords unique access to world-class cell culture facilities.

This study will utilize a novel capillary electrophoresis - laser-induced fluorescence (CE-LIF) pteridine detection technique to monitor 15 clinically important pteridines in an established human lung cancer cell line and normal human embryonic kidney cells which will be used as a control. Pteridine functionality will be determined through activation/inhibition of metabolic pathways using well-established methods. Cellular pteridine levels will also be characterized to predicate the elevated levels clinically reported in urine matrices. Simultaneous analysis by liquid chromatography - tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) will permit identification of new clinically useful pteridine derivatives. Pteridine profiles including the 15 clinically important pteridines and any newly identified pteridine derivatives will be produced for lung cancer and control embryonic kidney cell lines as a new diagnostic tool. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pteridines comprise a broad panel of functionally diverse metabolites thought to be involved in the one-carbon metabolism pathway centered on folate. Folate derivatives often serve as one-carbon donors in homocysteine metabolism, de novo purine nucleotide synthesis and DNA methylation. Importantly, epigenetic alteration including DNA methylation is a hallmark of carcinogenesis. However, low pteridine concentrations among other bioanalytical challenges have complicated efforts to comprehensively understand their role in cancer. Hence, advanced analytical techniques capable of monitoring intracellular pteridine derivatives are urgently needed to substantiate their clinical significance and specific function in cancer.

This East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes (EAPSI) project developed a high-throughput intracellular pteridine profiling technique using high-performance liquid chromatography – quadrupole time-of-flight mass spectrometry (HPLC-QTOF MS) to simultaneously quantify seven intracellular pteridines and semi-quantitatively monitor 18 additional, naturally-occurring pteridine derivatives. An accompanying pteridine extraction method using cold (-20 °C) aqueous methanol, dithiothreitol as an antioxidant, and ammonium hydroxide as a solubility enhancer, was also developed to effectively extract pteridine derivatives from the complex cell media to enable sensitive detection. The newly developed method was validated through evaluation of spiked recoveries (84.5% - 109.4%), reproducibility (2.1% – 5.4% RSD), method detection limits (0.1 – 3.0 µg/L) and limits of quantitation (0.1 – 1 µg/L), and finally application to non-small cell lung cancer A549 cells and human embryonic kidney HEK-293A cell lines. Twenty-three pteridine derivatives were successfully detected from cell lysates with an average RSD of 12% among culture replicates. Quantified intracellular pteridine levels ranged from 1 to 1000 nM in good agreement with previous studies. The resulting cell line-dependent pteridine values were compiled to generate novel pteridine profiles for the A549 and HEK-293A cell lines. These results indicated the newly developed method was both highly sensitive and selective. This method may therefore be used to investigate the specific pathophysiological functions of pteridine derivatives in order to support biomarker qualification efforts. These research findings additionally support the bioanalytical chemistry community by providing new knowledge related to overcoming specific bioanalytical challenges common to various metabolites such as pteridines.

This project was conducted in collaboration with Dr. Huwei Liu, a noted expert in bioseparations and bioanalysis, at Peking University in Beijing, China. This international collaboration afforded a unique opportunity for the U.S. graduate student researcher to conduct international research at a world-class foreign research institution. New knowledge and expertise has been acquired as a result of this collaboration leading to enhanced research capabilities. Through this work, long-lasting scientific partnerships have been formed with both young and established Chinese researchers. The collaborative relationship between Missouri University of Science and Technology and Peking University has also considerably strengthened from this work.

 


Last Modified: 02/28/2015
Modified by: Casey Burton
